story:
** Thanks to everyone who contributed to the campaign - which is now closed.

If you are reading this and have interest in still contributing to the project we're currently putting together an incentive package to fund a "leg" of the project - a trip for every few states to meet and photograph people. Please feel free to contact directly at ianbrownphoto@gmail.com for details. 

The project is still in the process of being photographed and will continue to be worked on throughout 2016. We have a new website launch in July 2016.








....Hi - My name is Ian Brown.

I live in Toronto, am a single dad to a 5 year old girl and I've been a documentary and portrait photographer for almost 20 years. 

In 2007 I was in the U.S taking portraits of American's and through the conversations that happen the theme of "being American" kept coming up with people. At the same time the election was underway and the idea of the "American Dream" kept coming up in the news. 

I'm not sure when exactly or why but it seemed like it would make sense to get people to write down what their own "American Dream" was. It's something that is always referenced and there is a vague idea of what it means, but I began to wonder what people really thought about it - in their own words.  

What unfolded was unexpected and amazing. People just didn't write trivial things but really heartfelt and personal thoughts and stories. 

Life kinda got in the way for awhile, health, having a kid, etc. and so I had to put things on the shelf for a few years - but I was always still aware that this is a really special project and important to continue. 

So, about a year ago I began making more portraits and getting people to share their stories. It meant lots of driving, sleeping in cars, going into sometimes sketchy situations and trying to convince everyday people that they have stories to share also.  


It's not easy to do -  It's ambitious and a bit epic in nature. It takes time and research and a commitment - not just on my part, but on the part of the people being photographed and adding their voice. This is not anonymous.

What I think makes this project different and special is that It's people from all facets of society - ordinary people who have extraordinary tales and extraordinary people who have simple aspirations - just like you and me. 


I always believe that a good portrait only happens when you invest some time and realize it has to be enriching for everyone involved. As a result people have really resonated with this and are not only willing to be part of this project but often are revealing thoughts and feelings that they have never shared before. 

The results are profound, beautiful, heartbreaking, funny, sometimes devastating and always intimate and revealing. As unique and individual as the people themselves. 


This is an important time in the history of the US. There are lots of issues and with the upcoming election the country is at a crossroads. The AMERICAN DREAMS PROJECT sets out to capture the stories of individual Americans, in their own words by their own hand. 

I've done this all on my own up until this point.  Now I'm asking for some help. 

I'm hoping to raise funds to complete the production of the project. The goal is to finish the project by summer 2016.

The finished project will be published into a large format book with each portrait displayed with the adjacent handwritten "American Dream" . There will be an accompanying National exhibition of the photos and there is hope that it would then be housed in a permanent collection or public archive. 



Once in awhile something comes along that becomes greater than the sum of it's parts. A legacy project that composes a true sense of where we are and who we are. Timely and also timeless. The American Dreams Project  aims to become just that. 

I'm hoping that you can help in whatever way you can. There are some cool incentives if you can contribute to the campaign. Otherwise feel free to share the project to your network and your friends. 

Everyone has a story to tell. This project is hoping to let people do that. 

Thanks so much!

Ian

It meant lots of driving, sleeping in cars, going into sometimes sketchy situations and trying to convince everyday people that they have stories to share also.  It's not easy to do -  It's ambitious and a bit epic in nature. It takes time and research and a commitment - not just on my part, but on the part of the people being photographed and adding their voice. This is not anonymous.What I think makes this project different and special is that It's people from all facets of society - ordinary people who have extraordinary tales and extraordinary people who have simple aspirations - just like you and me. 
I always believe that a good portrait only happens when you invest some time and realize it has to be enriching for everyone involved. As a result people have really resonated with this and are not only willing to be part of this project but often are revealing thoughts and feelings that they have never shared before. The results are profound, beautiful, heartbreaking, funny, sometimes devastating and always intimate and revealing. As unique and individual as the people themselves. 
This is an important time in the history of the US. There are lots of issues and with the upcoming election the country is at a crossroads. The AMERICAN DREAMS PROJECT sets out to capture the stories of individual Americans, in their own words by their own hand. I've done this all on my own up until this point.  Now I'm asking for some help. I'm hoping to raise funds to complete the production of the project. The goal is to finish the project by summer 2016.The finished project will be published into a large format book with each portrait displayed with the adjacent handwritten "American Dream" . There will be an accompanying National exhibition of the photos and there is hope that it would then be housed in a permanent collection or public archive. Once in awhile something comes along that becomes greater than the sum of it's parts. A legacy project that composes a true sense of where we are and who we are. Timely and also timeless. The American Dreams Project  aims to become just that. I'm hoping that you can help in whatever way you can. There are some cool incentives if you can contribute to the campaign. Otherwise feel free to share the project to your network and your friends. Everyone has a story to tell. This project is hoping to let people do that. Thanks so much!Ian

story: Hi, I'm Terry Gillis and I am a United States Marine Corps Veteran and aspiring singer/songwriter.  I was homeless back in 2009 and lived on the streets until I was taken in by the New Orleans Mission in 2011. For over 4 years I lived and worked at the Mission as one of their Disciples. Long ago, my dream was to share my music with the world but life had other plans. This past August, I was blessed to be featured at a unique jam session at the fabulous New Orleans Jazz Market in front of a huge crowd.  I was joined by many top Louisiana artists including Rockin' Dopsie Jr., John Autin, Eli Seals and more.  Together, we wrote a song with the help of the audience and it was amazing!  Our song is entitled, “On This Road Less Traveled” and I'm blown away by how good it is!  Now, we're taking the song into one of the best recording studios in the region!  All of the artists are donating their time to make this a reality, however, there are some hard costs that we need to cover.  We also need to raise money for making CD's once the song is recorded in addition to covering the costs for publishing and marketing.  Anything you can do to help us get our song recorded, mastered and distributed is greatly appreciated.  A portion of the proceeds from the song will benefit the New Orleans Mission to help them aid the homeless and hurting in our community.  Thank you and God bless!!!

For over 4 years I lived and worked at the Mission as one of their Disciples. Long ago, my dream was to share my music with the world but life had other plans. This past August, I was blessed to be featured at a unique jam session at the fabulous New Orleans Jazz Market in front of a huge crowd.  I was joined by many top Louisiana artists including Rockin' Dopsie Jr., John Autin, Eli Seals and more.  Together, we wrote a song with the help of the audience and it was amazing!  Our song is entitled, “On This Road Less Traveled” and I'm blown away by how good it is!  Now, we're taking the song into one of the best recording studios in the region!  All of the artists are donating their time to make this a reality, however, there are some hard costs that we need to cover.  We also need to raise money for making CD's once the song is recorded in addition to covering the costs for publishing and marketing.  Anything you can do to help us get our song recorded, mastered and distributed is greatly appreciated.  A portion of the proceeds from the song will benefit the New Orleans Mission to help them aid the homeless and hurting in our community.  Thank you and God bless!!!

story:
OVERVIEW

This is an adventure for me and my first time crowd funding. I am the son of a musician, Hans Lewitus, and am working towards producing a CD in honor of my father that compiles 61 of his songs performed by 3 Boston-based musicians.  Each song is unique and is representative of folk music from various Latin American countries such as Peru, Mexico, Venezuela, Brazil, Nicaragua, Uruguay, Bolivia, Panama, Ecuador, Chile, Costa Rica, Cuba, Haiti and Argentina.  All of the songs are performed on recorders, which was one of my father's favorite instruments.   My ultimate goal would be to submit this album to the Grammy's for a chance to see it win the Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album!  No goal is to big for me.   

FUNDING

The funding will go to the production, engineering and distribution of the CDs.  I have been able to use some of my personal savings to get the recordings underway and now I am looking for passionate music lovers to help finish the production of the CDs themselves.   Here is a sneak peek at the recording session.  It's worth a look!  https://youtu.be/ThMthWOGCzw

MORE ABOUT RECORDERS

What is a recorder? For those who learned it in elementary school there is no need to explain, for others:

From Wikipedia (why not keep it simple?)

The recorder is a woodwind musical instrument in the group known as internal duct flutes—flutes with a whistle mouthpiece.

Recorders are made in different sizes with compasses corresponding to different vocal ranges. The sizes most commonly in use today are the soprano (lowest note C5), alto (lowest note F4), tenor (lowest note C4) and bass (lowest note F3). Recorders are traditionally constructed from wood and ivory, although the use of plastics is now common. The recorder is first documented in the Middle Ages, and continued to enjoy wide popularity in the renaissance and baroque periods, but was little used in the classical and romantic periods. It was revived in the 20th century as part of the historically informed performance movement, and became a popular amateur and educational instrument.

ABOUT MY FATHER:

Hans Lewitus was born in Vienna on July 25, 1905.

He began piano lessons at age six, and music became a lifelong passion. While studying law he also went to the Conservatory of Music of Vienna, where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in clarinet in 1930. From then on music became his career.

In 1936, Professor Lewitus was recruited by the renowned violinist Bronislaw Huberman to become one of the founding members of the Palestine Symphony Orchestra. He played as principal clarinetist for the orchestra, which was originally led by the distinguished conductor Arturo Toscanini. After playing with the PSO for two years, Professor Lewitus was invited by Theo Buchwald to join the National Symphony Orchestra of Peru as principal clarinetist and one of its original members.

He spent the rest of his life in Lima, where, in addition to his position with the National Symphony Orchestra of Peru he was appointed as professor of clarinet at the National Conservatory of Music in Lima.  Professor Lewitus’ distinguished musical career included traveling to Caracas with Chabuca Granda, a beloved Peruvian folk composer and singer, as the director of her orchestra for the Festival de las Canciones. He also composed a mazurka and directed the music for her work "La Limeñísima.”  The theater director Ricardo Roca Rey asked him to compose incidental music for the production of Shakespeare’s “A Comedy of Errors,” and Professor Lewitus also composed the incidental music for  “Crossing  Niagara,” an acclaimed work by the Peruvian playwright and  director, Alonso Alegria.  Over the years he accompanied many international soloists on the piano.

Upon his retirement from the National Symphony Orchestra, Professor Lewitus began playing recorder and devoted himself to teaching privately piano, clarinet, and recorder. He also arranged Geistliche Lieder (sacred songs) of J.S. Bach for recorder quartets, published by B. Schott's Söhne. In 1980, Professor Lewitus’ arrangements of Latin American folk music for recorder were published by Otto Heinrich Noetzel Verlag. In 2009, I published Lima Romantica and Oda a Chabuca, music written for piano.

Professor Lewitus died in Lima, Peru on September 3, 1998.

MUSIC BOOKS

The songs on the album were selected from my father’s 13 books published in the early 1980s by Heinrichshofen & Noetzel in Germany.  They can be purchased by visiting  http://www.heinrichshofen.de

The recorder artists:

Aldo Abreu, recorder concert artist.  Performed throughout the U.S., Europe, New Zealand, Australia, Central America and his native Venezuela.  First Prize Winner of the 1992 Concert Artists Guild New York Competition.  Performances in Ambassador Auditorium in Los Angeles, the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall in New York.  Concerto soloist with Solisti New York and the Handel and Haydn Society, Boston Baroque and many others.  Faculty: New England Conservatory, Boston University, and Wellesley College.

 

Emily O’Brien is a native of Washington, DC where she played recorder from a young age. She studied recorder and french horn at Boston University, and recorder and Baroque flute at the Hochschule für Musik in Karlsruhe, Germany. She performs in recorder ensembles and historical chamber music, as well as English Country Dance bands, and is a former employee of the Von Huene Workshop and the Early Music Shop of New England in Brookline, MA. In her spare time, she enjoys long distance cycling.

 

Roy Sansom, recorder, has performed with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Boston Pops Orchestra, Boston Baroque, New World Symphony in Miami, BEMF Orchestra, New York City Opera and Emmanuel Music. He’s a featured soloist on the Telarc recording of Bach’s Brandenburg Concerti with the internationally acclaimed early music orchestra, Boston Baroque, with which he recently toured Poland performing in Monteverdi’s Vespers, and has recorded other works for Telarc and for Koch. Mr. Sansom composes for the recorder, scores for films and makes recorders at the von Huene Workshop in Boston.
